BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 7, 1923
CANCELLATION?
With a completed schedule before it, the basketball team finds
itself, for the third successive season, without a suitable floor for
practice, and will, in all probability, be compelled to disband. The
authorities at the Fifth Regiment Armory, which had been obtained,
have made it clear that the floor will be open only when convenient
to them. The athletic management, recalling last-moment cancellations and consequent losses of previous years, has decided to drop the
sport "unless satisfactory arrangements can be made."
The News-Letter regrets that basketball must be dropped. The
sport is an extremely interesting one and is a big drawing card in
Baltimore. Moreover, the advertisement that Hopkins will obtain
from writing to the largest colleges of the East and offering for
reason for the cancellation of a game the fact that "we have no floor"
will be far from advantageous to the University. We are not proud
of the fact that a university the size of ours should have ao gymnasium and we dislike to public the information.
The Trustees have inferred that the next addition to Homewood
buildings will be a gymnasium. We have been momentarily expecting an announcement that work will be started upon this unit. May
we suggest 'that when it is decided that Hopkins can erect such a
building, the first unit be a cage in which basketball and other sports
may be practiced and played?
In the meantime the basketball team is looking—somewhat hopelessly, we fear—for a floor, and the manager is cancelling the schedule.

HOW SHALL I SPEND MY TIME?
"How shall I spend my time?" This is the one big question of
the man of today—either in college or business life—but more so than
ever in college, with its multiplicity of activities and unceasing demands upon one's time.
Let us examine the question. Life today demands elimination
of the unessential and concentration upon the most important things.
"First things first" should be our motto. We should do first those
Things which our sense of values tells us are most essential, letting
the unimportant things "slide," as the saying goes.
With this necessity for doing the most important things first
clearly in mind the next thing is to determine what these things are.
This calls for a searching analysis of-all our daily activities, both personal. social and collegiate, in order to determine which are really
most important.
The problem for each man is different, depending on his sense
of relative values. One man may value a speaking acquaintance
with bar room loiterers and prizefighters more than familiarity with
the works of Shakespeare of the leading contemporary novelists.
Another may value a thorough knowledge of the scores of the football games more than familiarity with conditions in the United States
or Europe. He will be able to tell you that Podunk trimmed Oshkosh by a score of 17 to 3 last Saturday, but will be in the dark when
you discuss the Kaiser's probable return to Germany.
These illustrations show that ideas of relative importance differ—
that our sense of values is a varying quality.
Hence it is of first importance to get a clear cut idea of what
things are most important in life. And each man will solve this
problem differently. But having once thought these values out, he
is in a position to budget his time and allot to the things he considers
most important the major portion of his time—letting unimportant

COLLEGE GIRL OF TODAY
HAS GOOD PHYSIQUE,
SAYS PROFESSOR
Although the mental attiteade of
the college girl is frequently 'the
subject of attack, it has been recently brought to light that there
is still hope for her in the physical
side at least. Her point of view
May yet be at fault; but a series
of articles recently written by
Miss Mabel Newcomer, who is a
member of the Economics Department of Vassar College, bases her
statistics upon research work done
among the students there. Her
study has led her to the conclusion that the modern college girl
is far superior physically to those
of other days. She is putting on
weight and height, her waist
measurement is larger, and even
her lung capacity is improved.
The figures show that from 1884
to 1920 the average weight of college girls has increased from
123.8 to 125.8 lbs., the waist measurement dropped from 25 to 22
inches from 1884 to 1896, since
then has increased gradually until
it has reached 25 inches once more.
This growth, Miss Newcomer
feels, will give to the modern
women a far greater power Of endurance and a greater capacity for
work than she has ever had before. It points the way, ultimately, to an increased personal efficiency.
Miss Newcomer attributes the
general improvement in physical
interest in athletics taken by the
college girl. Not merely temporarily do sports aid her, but as a
source of permanent well-being.
As such, they should be sponsored in all the colleges to as
great an extent as possible.—
Wellesley College News.

sounds exactly right to a Washington and Lee man. Yet the traditional campus greeting of the

what you say as the spirit in
which you say it that counts.—

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 7, 1923
CANCELLATION?
With a completed schedule before it, the basketball team finds
itself, for the third successive season, without a suitable floor for
practice, and will, in all probability, be compelled to disband. The
authorities at the Fifth Regiment Armory, which had been obtained,
have made it clear that the floor will be open only when convenient
to them. The athletic management, recalling last-moment cancellations and consequent losses of previous years, has decided to drop the
sport "unless satisfactory arrangements can be made."
The News-Letter regrets that basketball must be dropped. The
sport is an extremely interesting one and is a big drawing card in
Baltimore. Moreover, the advertisement that Hopkins will obtain
from writing to the largest colleges of the East and offering for
reason for the cancellation of a game the fact that "we have no floor"
will be far from advantageous to the University. We are not proud
of the fact that a university the size of ours should have ao gymnasium and we dislike to public the information.
The Trustees have inferred that the next addition to Homewood
buildings will be a gymnasium. We have been momentarily expecting an announcement that work will be started upon this unit. May
we suggest 'that when it is decided that Hopkins can erect such a
building, the first unit be a cage in which basketball and other sports
may be practiced and played?
In the meantime the basketball team is looking—somewhat hopelessly, we fear—for a floor, and the manager is cancelling the schedule.

HOW SHALL I SPEND MY TIME?
"How shall I spend my time?" This is the one big question of
the man of today—either in college or business life—but more so than
ever in college, with its multiplicity of activities and unceasing demands upon one's time.
Let us examine the question. Life today demands elimination
of the unessential and concentration upon the most important things.
"First things first" should be our motto. We should do first those
Things which our sense of values tells us are most essential, letting
the unimportant things "slide," as the saying goes.
With this necessity for doing the most important things first
clearly in mind the next thing is to determine what these things are.
This calls for a searching analysis of-all our daily activities, both personal. social and collegiate, in order to determine which are really
most important.
The problem for each man is different, depending on his sense
of relative values. One man may value a speaking acquaintance
with bar room loiterers and prizefighters more than familiarity with
the works of Shakespeare of the leading contemporary novelists.
Another may value a thorough knowledge of the scores of the football games more than familiarity with conditions in the United States
or Europe. He will be able to tell you that Podunk trimmed Oshkosh by a score of 17 to 3 last Saturday, but will be in the dark when
you discuss the Kaiser's probable return to Germany.
These illustrations show that ideas of relative importance differ—
that our sense of values is a varying quality.
Hence it is of first importance to get a clear cut idea of what
things are most important in life. And each man will solve this
problem differently. But having once thought these values out, he
is in a position to budget his time and allot to the things he considers
most important the major portion of his time—letting unimportant

COLLEGE GIRL OF TODAY
HAS GOOD PHYSIQUE,
SAYS PROFESSOR
Although the mental attiteade of
the college girl is frequently 'the
subject of attack, it has been recently brought to light that there
is still hope for her in the physical
side at least. Her point of view
May yet be at fault; but a series
of articles recently written by
Miss Mabel Newcomer, who is a
member of the Economics Department of Vassar College, bases her
statistics upon research work done
among the students there. Her
study has led her to the conclusion that the modern college girl
is far superior physically to those
of other days. She is putting on
weight and height, her waist
measurement is larger, and even
her lung capacity is improved.
The figures show that from 1884
to 1920 the average weight of college girls has increased from
123.8 to 125.8 lbs., the waist measurement dropped from 25 to 22
inches from 1884 to 1896, since
then has increased gradually until
it has reached 25 inches once more.
This growth, Miss Newcomer
feels, will give to the modern
women a far greater power Of endurance and a greater capacity for
work than she has ever had before. It points the way, ultimately, to an increased personal efficiency.
Miss Newcomer attributes the
general improvement in physical
interest in athletics taken by the
college girl. Not merely temporarily do sports aid her, but as a
source of permanent well-being.
As such, they should be sponsored in all the colleges to as
great an extent as possible.—
Wellesley College News.

what you say as the spirit in
